entry.title: Conference and Talk
entry.content:
Writing this on the way back from the Applied Category Theory conference at the University of Florida.

All in all, I had a great time! The organizers did a great job, and there were loads of really interesting talks. I also got to meet a bunch of people working on cool stuff, and had a ton of great conversations. Guess that means a bunch of stuff to look up now that it’s over.

I also got to present some recent work on “partializations” of Markov categories,1 companion to (Fritz et al., 2025). It went good overall, even if a bit rushed due to the 30 minute time constraint. Good news is that people seemed to like it, and I got a fair number of questions and discussions after.

I will be heading to the International Category Theory conference in Brno next month, and hope to see some familiar faces there. Looking forward to it!

  1. I’m hoping the preprint will be out in not too much time. ↩

entry.title: New Preprint!
entry.content:
We1 have finished up a preprint (Fritz et al., 2025) for our work on empirical measures2 and laws of large numbers3 in the context of Markov categories (woohoo!).

This project had been on the back burner for a while, in fact before I’d even started my PhD! Although of course, the approach we’re using was developed somewhat more recently :). In fact, it got so big that we needed a bunch of machinery on “partialising” Markov categories that ended up getting split off into its own article. But that’s a topic that’s got a fair bit of interest on its own accord.

We should be presenting it at this years Applied Category Theory conference in June. Hope to see plenty of people there!

  1. Tobias Fritz, Tomáš Gonda, Antonio Lorenzin, Paolo Perrone, and I. ↩

  2. Intuitively given by the relative frequencies of a sequence of “samples”. ↩

  3. Or more generally, Glivenko-Cantelli theorems. ↩

entry.content: I recently happened to read The Rise and Fall of a Brown Water Navy: Sarkhel Kanhoji Angre and Maratha Seapower on the Arabian Sea in the 17th and 18th Centuries, written by Anirudh Deshpande and Muphid Mujawar. I’ve written more about it here, but the TL;DR is pretty good, would recommend.

entry.title: New Preprint!
entry.content:
We1 have finally finished up a preprint (Fritz et al., 2024) for our work on hidden Markov models2 in the context of Markov categories (woohoo!).

We’ve been at it for a while, I’d in fact presented this work at the Applied Category Theory 2023 conference3 back in the August of 2023. Of course, we’ve added a fair bit since then. For instance, the material on smoothing was all written after the conference. Still, it’s good to finally have something out :D

  1. Tobias Fritz, Andreas Klingler, Drew McNeely, Yuwen Wang and I. ↩

  2. Sometimes called state space models. ↩

  3. The recording is on YouTube. ↩
